<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SUPPLY CHAIN
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/03/31/chinas-factories-back-buyers?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Lockdowns Here Send Shockwaves Everywhere
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Ripples in still water " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC80MTcvcmlwcGxlX2VmZmVjdC5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">While China’s factory activity hit an all-time low in February, numbers released yesterday showed the country’s manufacturing sector started growing again in March. For all of us asking, “<em>When will this end?”</em> it’s a light at the end of the tunnel.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">A faint, flickering light—like the sign outside an old video store. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">China may be getting back to work, but the rest of the world is reading this in PJs. As major economies from the U.S. to India go into hibernation to slow the coronavirus pandemic, there’s <a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-china-economy-pmi-factory-official/china-factory-activity-unexpectedly-expands-but-economy-cannot-shake-off-virus-shock-idUSKBN21I05S?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">very little interest</a> in widgets made from Chinese assembly lines. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>“The biggest problem facing China’s economy in the second quarter is the slumping foreign demand,” economist Nie Wen told Reuters.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Orders for new Chinese exports, </span><span><a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-03-31/supply-chains-latest-not-made-in-china-is-tech-s-next-move?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">including steel</a></span><span>, are being canceled as the world waits out the outbreak.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">We’ve come full circle: </strong>A couple months ago, global supply chains were thrown into chaos when Chinese factories closed because of the coronavirus. Now that they’re back online, few companies are buying parts.   </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">The situation might be worse in Bangladesh</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The South Asian country is a <a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/health-coronavirus-bangladesh-exports/garment-exporter-bangladesh-faces-6-bln-hit-as-world-retailers-cancel-orders-idUSL1N2BO1A2?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">global hub</a> for the garment industry—garment exports accounted for 84% of the country’s total exports last fiscal year. Now, as apparel retailers shut their doors to observe social distancing policies, the market for those goods has evaporated.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The VP of a Bangladeshi trade association said all orders have been canceled or suspended until July. So far, that’s more than $3 billion lost. </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Canceled orders will likely force more factories to close. The country’s 4,600 garment factories support more than 4.1 million jobs, and industry leaders think the government’s $588 million relief package won’t be enough to help those workers.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>The coronavirus pandemic will cause a rethink of globalized supply chains, where right now a stay-at-home order in one country can affect millions of lives on the other side of the world.</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-top: 12px;">
<a href="https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2020%2F03%2F31%2Fchinas-factories-back-buyers" target="_blank" rel="noopener" style="text-decoration: none;" class="">

<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
WORKFORCE
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/03/31/amazon-whole-foods-workers-protest-coronavirus-working-conditions?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Essential Workers Don't Feel So Essential
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Walmart and Amazon were the No. 1 and 2 private U.S. employers before the pandemic and, with 250,000 open spots between them, will likely keep those titles. But being top purveyors of “essential” items is taking a toll on workers. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Yesterday, Whole Foods employees <a href="https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/business/2020/03/31/coronavirus-workplace-conditions-spur-protests-whole-foods-amazon/5093570002/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">organized</a> a “sick out” to pressure Amazon into providing improved workplace safety, benefits like hazard pay, and more sick pay—one day after dozens of Amazon’s NYC workers <a href="https://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/local/amazon-fires-staten-island-worker-who-organized-walk-out-protest-over-lack-of-coronavirus-protections/2352118/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">walked out</a>. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The problem?</strong> Consumers are shopping like it’s Dec. 23, but instead of Baby Yoda plushies they want TP and Lysol. But some warehouses are reportedly <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/amazon-struggles-to-find-its-coronavirus-footing-its-a-time-of-great-stress-11585664987?mod=hp_lead_pos5&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">operating</a> with half staff, and many employees working in close conditions don't have access to masks or gloves. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Employees of at least 15 U.S. Amazon facilities have been quarantined or tested positive for COVID-19.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Hoping to avoid that, Walmart is taking additional steps to protect workers, including measuring temperatures before shifts and offering face masks. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture: </strong>Amazon workers have complained for years about harsh working conditions. With the pandemic, they’ve had more leverage to secure additional time off, paid sick leave, and higher wages. </p>

<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
ECONOMY
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/03/31/economists-debate-trajectory-pandemiccaused-recession?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
We Like Our Recessions Like We Like Our Vendettas
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Learning toy using wooden L, U, W, and V letter shapes " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC80MjEvbGV0dGVyX3RveXMuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The bad news: </strong>The global economy is headed for a recession, if we’re not in one already. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The less bad news:</strong> Economists are still debating the trajectory of that recession. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Best-case scenario: </strong>like our favorite necklines—shaped like a V.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>If coronavirus cases decline and health authorities allow businesses to reopen, cooped-up consumers could embark on a spending spree that catapults output back up. </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Economists </span><span><a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-03-31/a-quick-rebound-from-virus-economists-have-reason-to-doubt-it?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">don’t think</a></span><span> this is likely. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Worst-case scenario: </strong>An L-shaped recession, <a href="https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/recession-recovery-coronavirus-alphabet-letter-shape-project-economic-when-analysts-2020-3-1029042463?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">where output plummets</a> to the floor and stays there. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>It brings us no joy to tell you, but this could happen. Scientists at Imperial College London said containment measures may be necessary for 18 months.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Medium-est case scenario:</strong> a “Nike swoosh”-shaped recession, to borrow Moody’s Chief Economist Mark Zandi’s term. That means a sharp drop, followed by a bounce in Q3 and a plateau in Q4. Another possibility is a W shape like the U.S. experienced in the early 1980s, where the economy contracts, then recovers, then repeats. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>A W on this is actually a V. </p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
TECH
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/03/31/apple-buys-popular-weather-app-dark-sky?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Dark Skies Over Cupertino
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Yesterday, Apple bought the popular weather app Dark Sky in <span style="text-decoration: line-through;">an effort to contain the coronavirus</span> a regular business transaction. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Why Dark Sky caught Tim Cook’s eye: </strong>The $3.99 app employs <a href="https://techcrunch.com/2020/03/31/apple-acquires-dark-sky-android-version-shutting-down-in-july/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">hyperlocal weather data</a>, so its forecasts are tailored for users’ specific locations rather than a general estimate for an entire zip code. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Apple's tight embrace means Google users are getting the boot. In July, Apple will shut down the Android version of the app. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Dark Sky also said it will cut off new signups to its API service, a database of historical weather data and forecasts that outside developers can use for their own projects. Apple said it’ll keep the API alive for existing users, like the Carrot Weather app, until the end of 2021.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>Apple says there will be “no changes” to the Dark Sky app on iOS. The question is, what's in store for Apple's Weather app? </p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
CALENDAR
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/03/31/morning-brews-daily-quarantine-planner-april-1?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Your Daily Quarantine Planner: April 1
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Brew writer Alex Hickey won't tell you she has impeccable taste, but...she has impeccable taste. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0"><img src="https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/athletic-shoe_1f45f.png" width="18" style="max-width:18px" alt=""> Morning workout </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Time for a high school throwback. <a href="https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCIJwWYOfsCfz6PjxbONYXSg?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Blogilates</a> is free and quick and has a decade’s worth of videos to choose from. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">
<strong style="color:#000"><img src="https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/earth-globe-europe-africa_1f30d.png" width="18" style="max-width:18px" alt=""> </strong>Events happening in cyberspace</h2>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Today at noon ET, Politico’s Pulitzer Prize-winning cartoonist Matt Wuerker is running a </span><span><a href="https://register.gotowebinar.com/register/5383528193767815436?source=moderator+social&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">free online workshop</a></span><span>. </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>At 6pm ET, our Head of People Ops Kate Noel is going live on Instagram to answer all your HR questions during this crazy time. You can find us at @morningbrew. </span></li>
</ul>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">
<strong style="color:#000"><img src="https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/headphone_1f3a7.png" width="18" style="max-width:18px" alt=""> </strong>Work playlist</h2>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Forget the four walls you’re stuck in with the </span><span><a href="https://qz.com/work/1823878/listen-to-nature-from-the-national-parks-to-stay-calm-and-focused/?utm_source=email&utm_medium=daily-brief&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">soothing sounds</a></span><span> of U.S. National Parks. </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><a href="https://open.spotify.com/artist/1QAJqy2dA3ihHBFIHRphZj?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Cigarettes After Sex</a></span><span> is great for chill and soothing background music. </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>TED’s excellent WorkLife podcast with business organization guru Adam Grant. </span><span><a href="https://tedtalks.social/wl?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="c-link" aria-describedby="slack-kit-tooltip" rel="noopener">Tune in here</a></span><span>.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0"><img src="https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/sandwich_1f96a.png" width="18" style="max-width:18px" alt=""> Lunch, but make it productive</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Level up: </strong>There are hundreds of Ivy League courses you can take online for free, like Harvard’s class on the <a href="https://www.classcentral.com/course/edx-science-cooking-from-haute-cuisine-to-soft-matter-science-part-1-811?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">science of cooking</a> or Yale's exploration of the <a href="https://www.classcentral.com/course/moralities-911?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">moralities of everyday life</a>. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Do good:</strong> Resurfacing the Brew’s <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/03/20/ways-help-coronavirus-epidemic?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">ways to help and donate</a> to pandemic response efforts.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Stay up-to-date: </strong>Did you forget there’s an election happening? UVA politics Prof. Larry Sabato has a weekly newsletter, <a href="http://centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">the Crystal Ball</a>, that tracks all the races underway.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0"><img src="https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/canned-food_1f96b.png" width="18" style="max-width:18px" alt=""> Dinner options</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">For something easy, <a href="https://www.foodandwine.com/recipes/pumpkin-risotto?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">pumpkin or butternut squash risotto</a> is my chicken soup. For something fancy, <a href="https://cooking.nytimes.com/recipes/12116-cornish-game-hens-canzanese?action=click&module=Global%20Search%20Recipe%20Card&pgType=search&rank=1&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Cornish game hens canzanese</a> (you can easily swap the hens with chicken thighs and the currants for pomegranate). For dessert, these <a href="https://cooking.nytimes.com/recipes/1018055-salted-tahini-chocolate-chip-cookies?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">salted tahini chocolate chip cookies</a> will get you through anything. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0"><img src="https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/television_1f4fa.png" width="18" style="max-width:18px" alt=""> Evening activity</h2>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">No screen: </strong></span><span>We started a book recommendation series, </span><span><a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/03/26/morning-brews-march-reads?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Brew’s Bookshelf</a></span><span>. Pick one of the great options and start your own quarantine book club. </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Screen: </strong></span><span>Work through the classics with these </span><span><a href="https://www.usatoday.com/story/entertainment/movies/2020/03/20/coronavirus-100-movies-watch-while-stuck-inside-and-quarantined/2870322001/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">100 movies</a></span><span> to watch while you’re stuck inside. Also, </span><span><a href="https://www.pbs.org/food/shows/great-british-baking-show/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"><em>The Great British Baking Show</em></a></span><span> has all the heartwarming content and bread inspiration you need during these times.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<hr>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><em><img src="https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/house-with-garden_1f3e1.png" width="18" style="max-width:18px" alt=""><strong data-stringify-type="bold" style="color:#000">We want you to live your best quarantined life</strong>—so much so, that we launched a brand new, free newsletter to be your guide. <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/the-essentials/?utm_medium=onsite&utm_campaign=dailyplanner_042020&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Check out The Essentials→</a></em></p>

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
GUESS THE LOGO
</h3>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">

style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0\"\u003e\nSUPPLY CHAIN\n\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px\"\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/03/31/chinas-factories-back-buyers?email={{profile.email}}\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nLockdowns Here Send Shockwaves style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eGetty Images\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWhile China’s factory activity hit an all-time low in February, numbers released yesterday showed the country’s manufacturing sector started growing again in March. For all of us asking, “\u003cem\u003eWhen will this end?”\u003c/em\u003e it’s a light at the end of the tunnel.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eA faint, flickering light—like the sign outside an old video store. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eChina may be getting back to work, but the rest of the world is reading this in PJs. As major economies from the U.S. to India go into hibernation to slow the coronavirus pandemic, there’s \u003ca href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/us-china-economy-pmi-factory-official/china-factory-activity-unexpectedly-expands-but-economy-cannot-shake-off-virus-shock-idUSKBN21I05S?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003every little interest\u003c/a\u003e in widgets made from Chinese assembly lines. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003e“The biggest problem facing China’s economy in the second quarter is the slumping foreign demand,” economist Nie Wen told Reuters.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eOrders for new Chinese exports, \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-03-31/supply-chains-latest-not-made-in-china-is-tech-s-next-move?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eincluding steel\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e, are being canceled as the world waits out the outbreak.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWe’ve come full circle: \u003c/strong\u003eA couple months ago, global supply chains were thrown into chaos when Chinese factories closed because of the coronavirus. Now that they’re back online, few companies are buying parts.   \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eThe situation might be worse in Bangladesh\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe South Asian country is a \u003ca href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/health-coronavirus-bangladesh-exports/garment-exporter-bangladesh-faces-6-bln-hit-as-world-retailers-cancel-orders-idUSL1N2BO1A2?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eglobal hub\u003c/a\u003e for the garment industry—garment exports accounted for 84% of the country’s total exports last fiscal year. Now, as apparel retailers shut their doors to observe social distancing policies, the market for those goods has evaporated.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe VP of a Bangladeshi trade association said all orders have been canceled or suspended until July. So far, that’s more than $3 billion lost. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eCanceled orders will likely force more factories to close. The country’s 4,600 garment factories support more than 4.1 million jobs, and industry leaders think the government’s $588 million relief package won’t be enough to help those workers.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eThe coronavirus pandemic will cause a rethink of globalized supply chains, where right now a stay-at-home order in one country can affect millions of lives on the other side of the world.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nEssential Workers Don't Feel So Essential\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWalmart and Amazon were the No. 1 and 2 private U.S. employers before the pandemic and, with 250,000 open spots between them, will likely keep those titles. But being top purveyors of “essential” items is taking a toll on workers. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eYesterday, Whole Foods employees \u003ca href=\"https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/business/2020/03/31/coronavirus-workplace-conditions-spur-protests-whole-foods-amazon/5093570002/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eorganized\u003c/a\u003e a “sick out” to pressure Amazon into providing improved workplace safety, benefits like hazard pay, and more sick pay—one day after dozens of Amazon’s NYC workers \u003ca href=\"https://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/local/amazon-fires-staten-island-worker-who-organized-walk-out-protest-over-lack-of-coronavirus-protections/2352118/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewalked out\u003c/a\u003e. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe problem?\u003c/strong\u003e Consumers are shopping like it’s Dec. 23, but instead of Baby Yoda plushies they want TP and Lysol. But some warehouses are reportedly \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/amazon-struggles-to-find-its-coronavirus-footing-its-a-time-of-great-stress-11585664987?mod=hp_lead_pos5\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eoperating\u003c/a\u003e with half staff, and many employees working in close conditions don't have access to masks or gloves. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eEmployees of at least 15 U.S. Amazon facilities have been quarantined or tested positive for COVID-19.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eHoping to avoid that, Walmart is taking additional steps to protect workers, including measuring temperatures before shifts and offering face masks. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture: \u003c/strong\u003eAmazon workers have complained for years about harsh working conditions. With the pandemic, they’ve had more leverage to secure additional time off, paid sick leave, and higher wages. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe bad news: \u003c/strong\u003eThe global economy is headed for a recession, if we’re not in one already. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe less bad news:\u003c/strong\u003e Economists are still debating the trajectory of that recession. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBest-case scenario: \u003c/strong\u003elike our favorite necklines—shaped like a V.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eIf coronavirus cases decline and health authorities allow businesses to reopen, cooped-up consumers could embark on a spending spree that catapults output back up. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eEconomists \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-03-31/a-quick-rebound-from-virus-economists-have-reason-to-doubt-it?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edon’t think\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e this is likely. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWorst-case scenario: \u003c/strong\u003eAn L-shaped recession, \u003ca href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/recession-recovery-coronavirus-alphabet-letter-shape-project-economic-when-analysts-2020-3-1029042463?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewhere output plummets\u003c/a\u003e to the floor and stays there. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eIt brings us no joy to tell you, but this could happen. Scientists at Imperial College London said containment measures may be necessary for 18 months.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eMedium-est case scenario:\u003c/strong\u003e a “Nike swoosh”-shaped recession, to borrow Moody’s Chief Economist Mark Zandi’s term. That means a sharp drop, followed by a bounce in Q3 and a plateau in Q4. Another possibility is a W shape like the U.S. experienced in the early 1980s, where the economy contracts, then recovers, then repeats. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eA W on this is actually a V. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eYesterday, Apple bought the popular weather app Dark Sky in \u003cspan style=\"text-decoration: line-through;\"\u003ean effort to contain the coronavirus\u003c/span\u003e a regular business transaction. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhy Dark Sky caught Tim Cook’s eye: \u003c/strong\u003eThe $3.99 app employs \u003ca href=\"https://techcrunch.com/2020/03/31/apple-acquires-dark-sky-android-version-shutting-down-in-july/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ehyperlocal weather data\u003c/a\u003e, so its forecasts are tailored for users’ specific locations rather than a general estimate for an entire zip code. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eApple's tight embrace means Google users are getting the boot. In July, Apple will shut down the Android version of the app. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eDark Sky also said it will cut off new signups to its API service, a database of historical weather data and forecasts that outside developers can use for their own projects. Apple said it’ll keep the API alive for existing users, like the Carrot Weather app, until the end of 2021.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003eApple says there will be “no changes” to the Dark Sky app on iOS.
